OEC) consists of two levels of power extraction, Level 1 (L1) and Level 2 (L2). The Iso Pentane in each of these levels are completely isolated from one another and each circulate in a closed loop. The turbine in each of these loops is directly coupled to a common generator. Each level has similar components with the exception that that the L2 cycle does not have a recuperator as does the L1 cycle. For each cycle the power extraction starts in heat exchangers (preheaters and vaporizers) which absorb heat from the geothermal brine in order to boil and convert the iso pentane into its vapor phase. The vaporized iso pentane is then directed to turbines specially designed to convert thermal energy in the vaporized iso pentane to rotational mechanical energy. The turbines which are directly coupled to the same generator, in turn, rotate the generator leading to the generation of electrical power. Iso pentane from the turbine is directed through a recuperator and then air-cooled condenser in the L1 cycle and directly to the air-cooled condenser in L2.  The condensers then complete the condensing of iso pentane back to its liquid phase. From the condensers iso pentane falls to the suction of the feed pumps which pressurize the iso pentane and direct the iso pentane through the regenerators, a non-contact heat exchange process, to absorb heat from the iso pentane moving from the turbine outlet to the condensers and to the preheater in the L1 cycle. In the L2 cycle iso pentane goes directly from the feed pumps to its preheater to start the cycle over again.

The Worst-Case Release Scenario and the Alternative Release Scenario.

  The Worst-Case Release Scenario evaluated was that of a ruptured iso pentane tank leading to a BLEVE condition using 166,637 pounds of iso pentane. The maximum distance to an over pressure of 1 psi is 0.4 miles (0.6 kilometers). The EPA's RMP Off site Consequence Analysis Guidelines for Worst-Case Scenario were calculated using RMP*Comp. Althoug

h there are numerous installed control measures that, in an actual event, would mitigate the release, no credit for mitigation measures was considered for this scenario.

  The Alternate Case Release Scenario evaluated is based on the rupturing of a filling hose during an iso pentane delivery between the delivery truck and storage tank. This leading to spill lasting 10 minutes and subsequently a pool fire starting before any mitigating efforts can take effect.  Using RMP*Comp to perform the calculations it is estimated that the initial iso pentane flow rate will be 2,320 pounds per minute leading to a heat radiation endpoint of 5 kw/square meter at 0.2 miles (0.4 kilometers) from the fire.

Additionally, it is the belief of Lightning Dock Geothermal management that this management program also lead to a more efficient and profitable operation.

The Process Safety Management program consists of thirteen program elements which comprise:

	PSM Program Management and Document Control
	Facility and Substance Information and Safety Information (PSI)
	Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)
	Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs)
	Training Programs
	Mechanical Integrity Program (MIP)
	Management of Change (MOC) Program
	Pre-Start Up Safety Review (PSSR)
	Verification of Compliance Audit
	Incident Investigation
	Employee Participation
	Contractor Safety Program
	Emergency Action Plan

The Accidental release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Soda Lake 3 (SL3) Geothermal Power Facility Executive Summary

  The SL3 Geothermal Power Facility is located at 5500 Soda Lake Way, Fallon, Nevada in the county of Churchill. The facility is committed to being a responsible member of the nearby communities. Site policy dictates that the SL3 Facility continuously identify methods to identify and reduce the risk to the community and environment through implementation of inherently safe technologies and procedures. This commitment to safe and environmentally sound operations is documented in policy and safety procedures at the facility which are available to all employees who are trained to these policies and safety procedures.

 Description of the Soda Lake 3 Unit Geothermal Facility and the Regulated Substance Used.

  The facility uses heat from geothermal brine at approximately 327 degrees Fahrenheit to heat, through a non-contact heat exchange process, a single iso pentane process that converts the geothermal heat to electric power for sale to the University of Utah through a wheeling agreement with the local utility (NV Energy) to meet their renewable electric power commitments. The iso pentane used in the closed loop (recirculated/recycled) power generation process is the only regulated substance at the site. The facility can have on site up to 36,000 gallons of iso pentane being used in the process or being stored. It is expected that, due to fugitive emission losses, no more than one truck of approximately 4,200 gallons of makeup iso pentane will be required per year and, in fact, continuous monitoring of leakages and proper maintenance will in all eventuality reduce fugitive emission losses and the need to replenish significantly. When iso pentane is delivered to the site it will be off loaded at a designated iso pentane storage area and under well qualified and approved safe operating procedures.

PSM Program Management and Document Control

Also, of importance are the ready identification, accessibility and appropriate archival management of such documentation. Evidence of compliance in this regard is a requirement of external authorities such as: 
It is also important that policies, procedures, process safety information and key materials are document controlled such that the relevant revision is readily identifiable by readers and users, as applicable at any specific time, especially for auditing and historical purposes.
The Plant Manager is responsible for an ongoing review all process safety information and procedures to make certain they are regularly updated in line with changing legislative and other requirements. All superseded process safety information and procedures are to be destroyed
An appropriate review process, incorporating employee consultation, is in place per the Employee Participation Program.
This policy applies to the Soda Lake 3 Risk Management Program.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

  To establish a procedure for conducting a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) for the Soda Lake 3 Geothermal Power Plant.  This procedure is required for compliance with OSHA Process Safety Management (OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119(e)).
  The purpose of the PHA is to:
	Define possible hazards associated with the facilities process that includes Iso-pentane. 
	Identification of any previous incidents, which had a likely potential for catastrophic consequences.
	Evaluate engineering and administrative controls applicable to the hazards.
	Determine the consequences of failures associated with engineering and administrative controls.
	Perform facility inspection and HAZOP study to determine the safety and health of employees.
	Establish a method of addressing team's findings and recommendations; assure the recommendations are resolved in a timely manner; document what actions are taken and a written schedule of when the actions are to be completed.
The PHA will be updated and validated every five years to ensure the study is consistent with the processes.

  Management of Change (MOC) procedures ensure proper process changes are evaluated for safety and health consequences and approved before being implemented.

  MOC procedures ensure that employees involved in operating a process, and maintenance and contract employees whose job tasks will be affected are informed of, and trained in, all elements of the PSM program and all CAPP elements.
  MOC will verify each process change will be audited to ensure the change has been properly reviewed and implemented as proposed, that proper documentation has been made to drawings, diagrams, operating procedures, and standard safety procedures and that subsequent operations, after the change has been implemented, have not indicated the existence of unrecognized hazards.
  The Plant Manager has the primary responsibility for ensuring all affected departments and employees (including contractors) have been informed about any process change prior to it being implemented.
  In order to maintain the continuity of a chemical process and allow for those instances where periodic fine-tune adjustments are required, an operator must have the flexibility to be able to make necessary process changes to process operating conditions. These process changes are allowable without the need of MOC forms if they are within the range of safe operating limits specified in the Operating Procedure.
  In order to maintain the integrity of an operating process and allow for those instances where Emergency actions are required, an operator must have the flexibility to take immediate actions to make necessary process changes to process operating conditions. These Emergency process changes are reserved for those situations that are legitimately urgent and require some type of immediate action to stabilize and bring a potentially catastrophic situation under control. Pre-Start Up Safety Review (PSSR)

  The Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) Program was developed to ensure completeness, operability and safety of all new or modified equipment, systems and subsystems; to assure that appropriate safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place; and to verify that a process hazard analysis has been performed.
  The PSSR includes the use of construction walk down checklists for mechanical, electrical and control systems, construction document audits, the verification of procedure development, performance of a PHA and MOC, verification of safety, operation and maintenance training and the documentation and correction of deficiencies and the confirmation of completion.

Incident Investigation

  Incident investigation is the process of identifying causes of incidents and implementing steps to prevent similar events from occurring. The intent of an incident investigation is for employers/employees to learn from past experiences and thus avoid repeating past mistakes. 
This procedure is designed to meet the strict criteria of OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM), and EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP).
  The Incident Investigation process should be applied to all Accidents, Incidents, Incidents that resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in, a catastrophic release, and Near Misses that occur. OSHA and NAC definitions of these conditions are as follows:
¿	Incident: An unplanned, undesired event that adversely affects completion of a task.
¿	Catastrophic Release: An uncontrolled emission, fire or explosion involving one or more highly hazardous substances or explosives that presents imminent and substantial endangerment to the health of the employees, the public health or the environment.  The term includes events that occur within a building or other structure that contains the substance or explosive.
¿	Accident: An undesired event that results in personal injury or property damage.
¿	Near Miss: An incident where no property was damaged and no personal injury sustained, but where, given a sl

ight shift in time or position, damage and/or injury easily could have occurred. Note: a Near Miss does not necessarily require a release of process fluids. Any incident that could have reasonably resulted in a catastrophic release under different circumstances should be considered a Near Miss

Mechanical Integrity Program

  Is used to assure the continued integrity of process equipment and that all process equipment is designed, constructed, installed, and maintained to minimize the risk of process releases.
  Identify and categorize all process equipment and instrumentation.
  Development of written maintenance procedures and a quality assurance program.  
  Training for process maintenance activities, inspection and testing, and correction of deficiencies in equipment that is outside acceptable limits as defined by the process safety information. 
  This procedure is to be managed in accordance with SSP-1 - Program Management Plan and Document Control.

Management of Change (MOC) Program

  The intent of this procedure is to require management of all modifications to equipment, structures, buildings, procedures, raw materials and processing conditions other than replacement in kind by identifying and reviewing them prior to implementation of the change. Minimum requirements for management of change include: establishing written procedures to manage change; addressing the technical basis, impact on safety and health, modification to operating procedures, necessary time period, and authorizations required; informing and training employees and contractors affected; and updating process safety information and operating procedures or practices.

  The following is a list o

f examples but is not limited to where an MOC procedure is necessary:
    New projects that involve tie-ins, equipment additions or modifications, increase throughput or the use of a different raw material or additives.
    Significant changes in operating conditions, including pressures, temperatures, flow rates or process conditions outside the established ranges set for the process and mechanical design.
   Changes in alarms, instrumentation and control schemes.
   Changes to the process equipment that cause changes in the facilities pressure relief requirements.
   Bypass around equipment normally in service or running without equipment normally in service.
   Changes in operating procedures, including procedures for start-up, normal shutdown and emergency shutdown.
   Temporary connections, utilities, electrical, process, temporary repairs, pipe clamps. Etc.
   Replacement of components that are not in kind including gaskets, valves, bolts, etc. A MOC is not required for components which satisfy the in use/approved design specifications.
   Replacement of equipment with equipment of different design specifications, a change of manufacturer does not require an MOC if the specifications for the new equipment are the same as the one removed.
